column135:
24/Jul/19 11:46 PM;bstasyszyn;The InstantiateCC function does not look at the endorsement policy when targeting peers. (The instantiation policy is different from the endorsement policy.) By default, the instantiation policy is 'one-of-any', meaning that any org can endorse the instantiate proposal. If you choose to target only a subset of peers for install then you'll need to target (one or more of) those same peers for instantiate using WithTargets or WithTargetEndpoints. e.g.:

resmgmt.InstantiateCC(chID, req, WithTargetEndpoints("peer0.org1.example.com"))

(Note that the SDK doesn't currently support automatically selecting peers using the instantiation policy.)
;;;
column136:
25/Jul/19 2:41 PM;mtng;Sure, but in the documentation is written the following:

"By default, endorsement policies are specified for a channel’s chaincode at instantiation or upgrade time (that is, one endorsement policy covers all of the state associated with a chaincode)."

[https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.4/endorsement-policies.html?highlight=endorsement%20policy#two-ways-to-require-endorsement]

"Chaincode-level endorsement policies can be specified at instantiate time using either the SDK (for some sample code on how to do this, click [here|https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-node/blob/f8ffa90dc1b61a4a60a6fa25de760c647587b788/test/integration/e2e/e2eUtils.js#L178]) or in the peer CLI using the {{-P}}switch followed by the policy."

*[https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.4/endorsement-policies.html?highlight=endorsement%20policy#setting-chaincode-level-endorsement-policies]*

So I understand that the instantiation policy that i am defining is going to be the endorsement policy of that chaincode in that channel.

 

If I am defining only one organization to endorse the transaction, why the sdk is sending the request to all the organizations? I don't care about the peers in the endorse organization, both of them in that org have the chaincode installed.;;;

column32: At the moment, the SDK supports only one CA instance per organization. In the real world, an organization can be associated with multiple CAs. For example, an organization can have one CA for enrolling fabric users and another one for issuing TLS certificates for the organization.

column1: Make Service Discovery client usable outside of sdk
column32:
Right now Service Discovery client is used only internally by SDK, it can't be used outside because Request struct is in internal pkg, so client users are not able to create the Request struct. 
 [https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-go/blob/master/pkg/fab/discovery/discovery.go#L61]

Also, some of the Request methods require other structs from internal pkg (ChaincodeCall, ChaincodeInterest).

How to fix this:
 1. add a public constructor for the Request
 2. add a public method for creating ChaincodeCall from cc name. 
 3. add a public method for creating ChaincodeInterest from ChaincodeCall (using #2 as an argument)

No API change
 No internal business logic change

column1: CA name is used as the CA identity
column32:
SDK configuration providers currently use CA name as the CA identity (lookup key). There are several problems with conflating the two. CA names might not be unique across the network (they are guaranteed to be unique only within one CA server instance). This also forces the CA definition to have CA name, which is optional and may not even be defined on the CA server.

CA should have an ID property independent from the CA name, to be used as a unique identifier of a CA within a network.

column1: add feature to avoid event client disconnect from peer

*Current behaviour:*

the event client will disconnect from the peer if the peer's block height falls behind the specified number of blocks and will reconnect to a better performing peer.
  Note that this parameter is only applicable if peerMonitor is set to Enabled (default).
 Default: 10

*Proposal:*

Add a feature, if set to (0 or -1), event client disconnect should never happen.

column1: Ability to marshal protobuf messages from and to JSON

This is desired in scenarios when fabric protobuf data (e.g. channel configuration) needs to be exported/imported from/to a Fabric network.

At the moment, the SDK works on protobuf messages in a namespace that is different from the namespace used by Fabric, so the native Fabric JSON marshalling/unmarshalling cannot be applied. This change exposes JSON marshalling/unmarashalling of messages in the SDK namespace.

column1: Ability to update channel configuration
column32:
Currently, the only way to change channel configuration using SDK is to submit a pre-calculated channel update transaction.

Calculating a channel update transaction is not straightforward. From the client's point of view, it is desirable that SDK performs this calculation. In that case the client would only need to prepare updated channel configuration and submit to the SDK, which would then calculate and submit the channel update transaction to the orderer.

column1: Multi-org channel config update
column32:
SaveChannel ([https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-go/blob/3b103fa1b5703e03ed5315b78d07ab7bb96cbfd1/pkg/client/resmgmt/resmgmt.go#L927]) and UpdateChannelConfig ([https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-go/blob/3b103fa1b5703e03ed5315b78d07ab7bb96cbfd1/pkg/client/resmgmt/resmgmt.go#L984]) provide methods for creating and updating a channel configuration. There are problems with usage of these methods in a general case when a change (a new channel configuration or an update) has to be signed by multiple orgs.
 # Both methods allow passing in a list of signing identities ([https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-go/blob/3b103fa1b5703e03ed5315b78d07ab7bb96cbfd1/pkg/client/resmgmt/resmgmt.go#L117]). If the list is passed in the request, SDK signs the configuration change on behalf of the provided identities (otherwise the change is signed only by the caller). This is problematic as keys from one org shouldn't be available to other orgs to sign with. The correct way to go about signing by multiple orgs is to use WithConfigSignatures option ([https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-go/blob/d2b42602e52e051adfe74fef3d99badc0b2b4250/pkg/client/resmgmt/opts.go#L115).] The channel config update Tx should be signed by multiple orgs out of band and all signatures should be submitted by one org, as demonstrated by test case at [https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-go/blob/3b103fa1b5703e03ed5315b78d07ab7bb96cbfd1/test/integration/e2e/orgs/multi_orgs_ch_update_signatures_test.go#L70].
 # UpdateChannelConfig was motivated by the need to have a simplified workflow where SDK client could retrieve channel configuration as protobuf, make changes to the configuration, and submit it back to SDK for simple channel update. While it is very convenient when it is sufficient to sign the change by only one org (the caller), It is not useful in the more general case when the change has to be signed by multiple orgs. One useful function provided by UpdateChannelConfig is calculation of channel config update Tx based on the diff between the desired channel config and current channel config. This function is, however, not exposed by SDK. The correct way to go about the use case with multiple orgs is to expose the ability to calculate the config change Tx. This would enable a workflow in which the participating orgs would be able to independently calculate the channel update Tx based on the proposed configuration change, sign it, and then one org could use the existing SaveChannel(WithConfigSignatures) to submit the change. UpdateChannelConfig would then become redundant.

Proposed code changes:
 # Deprecate SaveChannelRequest.SigningIdentities ([https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-go/blob/3b103fa1b5703e03ed5315b78d07ab7bb96cbfd1/pkg/client/resmgmt/resmgmt.go#L117])
 # Replace UpdateChannelConfig with CalculateConfigUpdate function which calculates channel update Tx based on the desired channel config and current channel config.
 # Write an integration test to demonstrate the following workflow:
 ## Retrieve current channel config as protobuf
 ## Produce the desired channel config by making changes to current config
 ## Calculate channel update Tx based on the diff between current and desired channel config
 ## Sign the channel update Tx by multiple orgs
 ## Use SaveChannel(WithConfigSignatures) to update the channel config
 ## Verify that the change is correctly applied
 ## Of course, coordination between orgs to communicate the desired channel config and collect signatures is out of scope of SDK.

column1: PKCS11 Context Handle to recover while getting session
column32:
Currently, PKCS11 resilience logic validates only sessions from pool or the one created by by OpenSession().

Recovery should also kick in if OpenSession() fails to return session and throws error due to any technical issues.

Context Handle also shouldn't panic once it exhausts all the attempts to recover session, it should return error so that any process trying to open session can retry after some time. (Helps when there is a network downtime)

column1: Fail-fast for Discovery Service
column32:
When a request is sent to the Discovery Service and MaxTargets is set to > 1 then, even though a response is received from one peer, we wait for ALL other requests to complete. When a peer is down then (depending on the connection settings) this may take a long time given GRPC's retry logic.

A modification should be made so that the requests to other peers are canceled as soon as a successful response is received.
column76: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Discovery client doesn't cancel dial
column32: When a Discovery request is received from a peer then all outstanding requests are cancelled (see FABG-913). Although, if the outstanding request is in the process of dialling a server that's down, it will wait for the connection timeout, since the provided context is not used in the GRPC Dial. The provided context should be used as the parent context to the dial so that the dial is immediately cancelled.

column1: Fix versionCapabilityPattern to allow three version numbers
column32:
Currently the versionCapabilityPattern in pkg/fab/chconfig/chconfig.go won't match version strings that have three version numbers like V1_4_3.

Suggest replacing the pattern with regexp.MustCompile(`^V(\d+)\_(\d+)(\_(\d+))?$`).

When the application capability version is set to V1_4_3 only, this should be good for all lower capability versions too. With this bug present, V1_4_3 is not treated as a version and so the capability V1_2 will not be recognized either and (for example) the discovery service won't work properly.

column1: Transition to pulling LAST_CONFIG from SIGNATURES metadata field
column32:
As with FAB-15795 we are trying to consolidate the assorted block metadata fields in use by the orderer under the single 'signature field'. The last config value is stored in the new way, but, it is still being written to the old location for backwards compatibility reasons.

The SDK should now use the last config index as found in the SIGNATURES field to retrieve the most recent config block.

column1: Simplify upstream patching
column32:
Fabric-sdk-go reuses fabric and fabric-ca code by first copying desired files from upstream repos and then patching them to work locally. The process of patching involves running shell scripts containing sed commands and applying additional pre-prepared git patches. It is very complicated and difficult to maintain.

Here we propose simplification of the way fabric code is reused. The new method still has two steps - copying from upstream and patching, but patching is now a simple git merge which replays changes from the last successful patch. For this to work, the two steps (pulling files from upstream and patching) must always be maintained in their own separate commits each time we pull in the new upstream version.

Note that replaying changes from old commits using a simple 'git am' doesn't work well because a git patch created with 'git format-patch' doesn't have a knowledge of the common ancestor of the master and the commit we want to replay, so we end up with many unexpected conflicts.

Here are full steps for pulling code from upstream and patching:

> make thirdparty-pin

We must now commit upstream files first. This will
keep the subsequent patch in its own clean commit so we can use it in the future.
 > git add .
 > git commit --signoff -m "Apply upstream"
 
Now we need to replay changes from the last correct patch. We do it using git, with the help of a temporary branch where we first copy the changes we want to replay. This example assumes that the last correct patch was committed as ‘5678’, and its parent is the commit ‘1234’.
 > git format-patch --stdout 1234..5678 > ~/last.patch

> git checkout -b fix 1234
 > git am ~/last.patch
 > git checkout master
 > git merge fix
 
If necessary, fix any conflicts and commit
Amend as required, and push all commits.

column1: Honor Orderer Exclude if configured in SDK
column32:
The fabric-sdk-go should exclude the Orderer(s) if entityMatcher is set to ignore undefined Orderers.
 Currently the code tries to use matching for config, if doesn't find it, it takes the config from channel configuration.
 The behavior should be to ignore Orderer if they dont exist in Configuration and to not look Orderer up in channel configuration.
 Sample config:
{code:java}
# --- ORDERERS ---------------------------------------------------------------
orderers:
  orderer1:
    url: orderer1.example.com
    grpcOptions:
      grpc-max-send-message-length: 15
    tlsCACerts:
      path: /tmp/tls.pem
  orderer2:
    url: orderer2.example.com
    grpcOptions:
      grpc-max-send-message-length: 15
    tlsCACerts:
      path: /tmp/tls.pem
  orderer3:
    url: orderer3.example.com
    grpcOptions:
      grpc-max-send-message-length: 15
    tlsCACerts:
      path: /tmp/tls.pem
  orderer4:
    url: orderer4.example.com
    grpcOptions:
      grpc-max-send-message-length: 15
    tlsCACerts:
      path: /tmp/tls.pem
  orderer5:
    url: orderer5.example.com
    grpcOptions:
      grpc-max-send-message-length: 15
    tlsCACerts:
      path: /tmp/tls.pem

#
# Used to match discovered entities.
#
entityMatchers:  # orderer matchers
  orderer:
    - pattern: orderer1.example.com:12345
      mappedHost: orderer1
    - pattern: orderer2.example.com:12345
      mappedHost: orderer2
    - pattern: orderer3.example.com:12345
      mappedHost: orderer3
    - pattern: orderer4.example.com:12345
      mappedHost: orderer4
    - pattern: orderer5.example.com:12345
      mappedHost: orderer5    

    - pattern: (\w+)-(\w+)-(\w+).(\w+).(\w+).(\w+):(\d+)
    #- pattern: (\w+):(\d+)
      ignoreEndpoint: true
{code}

column1: Add support for extra hosts at enrollment

Currently version of msp.Enrollment don't provide a "WithHosts" options for enrollment operation, even though ca api expose this option in a field named CSR of type CSRInfo. 
I think we should provide a WithHosts option, in some environments one dns entry for node isn't possible.

Real life problem: 
we have production environments that for some especial characteristics can't use just CN for tls, but rather the machine's public/private ip as well. This can be done by adding these hosts to certificate SANs.
I'm submitting a fix myself to this problem and hope that you point me how to finish the commit :)

column1: Add support for generating CRL with Revoke
column32:
Currently in the SDK there's no *GenCRL* field in the *msp.RevocationRequest*. The *msp.RevocationResponse*, which has *RevokedCerts* and *CRL* fields, comes with an empty *[]byte* for the *CRL,* so it's impossible to revoke a cert and then add de CRL to the config block, as required.

We must, then, add the *GenCRL* option in the necessary places.

After dig into sdk code , I found  sdk initialize key store with specific `SKI_sk`

which I think is not appropriate. Auto detect key file with suffic `_sk` or just use the file under dir `keystore` is more comprehensive or we can use file with name `SKI_sk` or `priv_sk` to support fabric1.x and fabric2.0

column1: MSP validation failure for Fabric versions >= 1.4.3
column32:
Networks that take advantage of OU roles ([https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.4/membership/membership.html#node-ou-roles-and-msps]) don't work with GoSDK clients due to failures when validating certificates.  This is because it is invoking internal Fabric validation code which is sensitive to version.  This level of validation is not done by the Node and Java SDKs.

A simple fix to this is to change the version number which has been hardcoded here:

[https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-go/blob/master/pkg/fab/channel/membership/membership.go#L170]

 

A PR is on its way.

Thanks!

column1: Gateway package not working with namespaced contracts
column32:
The new programming model for smart contracts includes the ability to have multiple contract classes in a single chaincode instance. The SDKs support this model with a two argument form of the getContract() method.

See [https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.4/developapps/chaincodenamespace.html#usage]

 

This was missed from the Go implementation in pkg/gateway, so needs adding.

column1: Retry message parsing needs to be updated for v2
column32:
Negative integration tests seem to be failing due to retry on chaincode not found not firing.

https://dev.azure.com/Hyperledger/Fabric-SDK-Go/_build/results?buildId=16854&view=logs&jobId=133bd042-0fac-58b5-e6e7-01018e6dc4d4&j=133bd042-0fac-58b5-e6e7-01018e6dc4d4&t=35dd90d0-ef00-5e9b-2929-828c5f8b2d4b

(500) UNKNOWN. Description: make sure the chaincode exampleCC2 has been successfully defined on channel orgchannel and try again: chaincode exampleCC2 not found

The code to determine retries does not appear to match the above string anymore:
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-go/blob/7dc798e62cb60e782ad5d223aa469765e034f8c9/pkg/fab/peer/peerendorser.go#L280

I assume other text-based parsing is also now broken for v2.

column1: Go SDK support for Service Discovery endorsement "NoPrivateReads"
column32:
SDKs can pass collection names to the Service Discovery endorsement service, so that service discovery considers peer collection membership and collection level endorsement policy (if set).

The SD endorsement flag "NoPrivateReads" can also be passed to indicate to SD that peers that are not members of the collection can also be considered, e.g. in the case of blind writes which is sometimes used to transfer an asset from one org's collection to another org's collection.

column1: Need a setEndorsingOrganizations function that picks available endorsing peers based on Service Discovery peers query
column32:
The Service Discovery 'endorsement query' can return many layouts, and if there is a very large number of layouts, SD will return a reduced list.

For many transactions, there is no need to do the endorsement query at all. For example when doing a transaction between Org1 and Org2 with private data, the client knows that they should target a Org1 peer and a Org2 peer already.

If the 'endorsement query' were used, the SDK either has to filter through many undesired layouts, or worse, the desired layouts may have already been filtered out on server side.

Therefore it should be possible to setEndorsingOrganizations simply based on the simpler and faster SD 'peers query', where the SDK picks one of the returned available peers from each targeted MSPID.

In terms of picking a peer, the SDK should use some combination of highest height and randomization. For example if two peers are within a block of each other, the SDK should randomize the choice. However if one peer is well ahead of another peer, the SDK should choose the higher height peer.
